div1.p: IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
IN THE MATTER OF THE UNLAWFUL DETENTION OF PALA SINGH, HINDOO ALIEN.
ORDER TO SHOW CAUSE.
FILED IN THE U.S. DISTRICT COURT, Western Dist. of Washington, NORTHERN DIVISION AUG 20 1913
FRANK L. CROSBY, Clerk,
By Emy Deputy
HERBERT W. MEYERS ATTORNEY AT LAW 430-431-432-433 PIONEER BUILDING PHONE MAIN 1278 SEATTLE, WASH.
MERCHANTS PRINTING CO., TIMES BLDG., SEATTLE
IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Unlawful Detention of Pala Singh, Hindoo Alien.
No. 2532. PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS.
TO THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT, FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION:
The petition of Pala Singh respectfully shows:
That your petitioner is a former resident of the Philippine Islands and is at this time unlawfully detained by the immigration authorities at the immigration station, Seattle, Washington.
-II-

That your petitioner was lawfully admitted at a regular immigration port of entry, Manila, Philippine Islands; was duly examined by an immigration board and duly examined by medical officers of the United States government, and passed by said immigration officials at the said City of Manila, as being fit and proper person to land in the territory held and controlled by the United States government, and as being strong and healthy enough and free from disease, to be entitled to pass the medical offices of the said immigration department; said immigrant was duly landed and lived for a short time in the City of Manila and in the Philippine Islands, with the knowledge of the United States government.
-III-

That your petitioner is now imprisoned and restrained of his liberty and detained by color of the authority of the United States in the custody of the Commissioner of Immigration, Seattle, Washington, at the immigration detention house in said city.
-IV-

That the sole claim or authority, by virtue of which the said Commissioner of Immigration has restrained and detains your petitioner is a certain warrant of arrest based upon Sections 2 and 20 of the Act of February 20, 1907, as amended by the Acts of March 26, 1910 and March 4, 1913, which warrant was issued contrary to law and without any foundation in law.

That the alien and your petitioner represents that he was not given a fair and impartial hearing, as is contemplated by law; that the immigration officials and inspectors were biased and prejudiced, which facts can be shown by affidavits or viva voce testimony, if he is given permission to be heard by this Honorable Court; that new testimony can be produced showing that it would be an absolute impossibility for this alien to become a public charge, and showing that never has been a time since his landing on the soil of the United States when he was even likely to become a public charge. This petitioner has had his constitutional gauranty denied him, and the entire proceeding from the landing of the petitioner on the steamship "Minnesota" has been a proceeding conducted not in accordance with law; that the authority, so called, excercised by the Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, the Commissioner General of Immigration and the Secretary of Labor, have not been fairly excercised, in justice, or in accordance with law; said officials have not acted within the
jurisdiction conferred upon them or in accordance with the provision of the act affecting such cases. The government has contended that this man violated some law on entering, which is not true, and there has never been any evidence before any of the government officials showing any violation of law, but is much evidence showing a proper landing, the inspection and examination of the alien, in accordance with law. No evidence showing the condition of the alien when he was examined the first time in Manila has been produced. The alien, having once been examined, in accordance with law, and passed, the second attempted examination is improper, and not in accordance with law, and in direct violation of the Act of February 20, 1907, as amended; that your petitioner is not an alien immigrant, within the meaning of the Act, having entered under a previous proper examination at Manila. Your petitioner produced evidence which was not met by the government, which positively proves that the government's contention was untrue; that the alien has been denied his constitutional gauranties; that he has been held and threatened with deportation, without having been given the equal protection of our laws and he is being twice put in jeopardy, and he has had no hearing and no testimony has been introduced showing him to come within the confines of the Act upon which the government has based this warrant for deportation, this alien has further been deprived of his rights as outlined in Article V, VI, VIII and XIV of the Amendments to the Constitution of the United States.
-VI-

That the issuing of the warrant, the holding of the examination by the immigration board at Seattle and on the steamship "Minnesota", the decision of the board at Seattle, and the decision of the Secretary of Labor, or his representative, in denying the rights of your petitioner to land at Seattle, were all
contrary to law and in direct violation of the Act of February 20, 1907, as amended.
-VII-

That there was abuse of authority on the part of the immigration board, and the Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle and the Secretary of Labor, or his representative, at Washington, in denying your petitioner the right to land at Seattle, as there is absolutely no proper evidence upon whihc to base a decision.
-VIII-
That your petitioner's imprisonment, restraint and detention are in violation of his rights, privileges and immunities, under the Constitution and laws of the United States for the following reasons:
First: That your petitioner had once been duly examined and passed and could not lawfully be again examined, in accordance with law.

Second: The issuing of the warrant was contrary to law, and especially contrary to the Act of February 20, 1907, as amended by the Act of March 4, 1913, for the reason that your petitioner had never become a charge and had shown no likelihood of becoming a charge, but on the other hand has affirmatively shown that there was no likelihood of his ever becoming a charge; that this man was examined at Manila under authority of the Act of February 20, 1907, and if so, that examination was final and the second examination at Seattle improper.
-IX-

That there was no evidence before the immigration board, the Commissioner, or the Secretary, upon which to base the ruling of the board in rejecting the petitioner, and in requesting a warrant, or the Secretary in ordering this alien deported.

The alien resided a short time in the Philippine Islands and never became a public charge or showed any likelihood of becoming a charge, and as he was taken in custody immediately upon arrival of the vessel, it cannot be said that he has become a charge, as he has been in custody ever since leaving Manila, and he has had no opportunity to show the fallacy of the government's position.
-XI-

The Act of February 20, 1907, provides that a head tax of Four ($4) Dollars shall be collected. This man paid this head tax when he was examined at Manila, and was not compelled to pay the same on his arrival in Seattle; this provision and the law indicating that the men are supposed to pay thsi fee but once, and by inference they are not supposed to be examined more than once. The Act itself specifically provides that is to apply to and regulate the immigration of aliens into the United States.

Section six (6) of the Act of February 20, 1907, provides that this Section was applied to the states and territories, the District of Columbia, or places subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.
By referring to Section twelve (12) and the last ten lines thereof, it will be noted that aliens coming from points in the United States are treated differently from those coming from foreign ports.

Section thirty-three (33) provides that for the purpose of the Act above quoted the words "United States" shall be construed to mean the United States and any waters, territory or other place subject to the jurisdiction thereof, except the Isthmian Canal only.
-XII-

It will be noted by referring to page twenty-eight (28)
of the Regulations of July 1, 1907, paragraph "G" thereof, that the aliens who have come from contiguous territory in the United States, namely from Manila, are subject to different disposition than those who have come from a foreign port.
-XIII-
The Commissioner of Immigration is threatening, unless restrained, to deport this petitioner on authority of a warrant which was improperly issued and has no basis in law.
-XIV-
That the warrant issued is fatally defective in that it does not comply with law and in particular does not comply with the Act of February 20, 1907, as amended.
-XV-
That the alien is not amenable to the law, which is the basis for the issuance of this warrant.
-XVI-
That the Secretary of Labor, rendering the decisions in these cases, has violated the law, and particularly the Act of February 20, 1907, as amended by the Acts of March 26, 1910, and March 4, 1913.
-XVII-

This Honorable Court has jurisdiction for the reason that there is a question of law involved, viz: whether the alien, who presented an alien's certificate, form No. 546, which certificate was signed by the Insular Collecter of Customs, and which showed the due inspections and registration of the alien and contained the following language "Will be admitted into the United States upon proper identification and surrender of this certificate to any immigration officer at a designated port of entry", and which certificate further contained the following "head tax paid", whether the government, in view of that certificate and
the examination at Manila, had the right to reexamine at Seattle or Tacoma.
-XVIII-

That a copy of the warrant is not attached here to for the reason that the same is in the hands of the Immigration Department and has never been furnished to the alien or his attorney, said warrant contained langauge in substance to this effect: "Said alien is a member of the excluded class in that he was afflicted with trachoma, a dangerous and contagious disease at the time of his entrance into the United States and that he was at the time of such entrance a public charge."
-XIX-

The alien having been passed as sound in July and there being competent testimony to he effect that the alien is not afflicted at this time, the government cannot contend that the alien comes within the confines of the Act.
-XX-
Trachoma, by the record, is shown to be a curable disease, even if the alien had suffered with the same.
-XXI-
The alien being, from the testimony, in the non-contagious class, it cannot be said that alien is suffering with a dangerous and contagious disease, as charged in the warrant of arrest.

WHEREFORE, your petitioner prays that a writ of habeas corpus directing the immigration officals to bring the said alien petitioner in court and to show cause of his detention, or for an order to show cause directing the immigration officals to appear in court on a day certain answer the
petition herein filed, and to show cause why the said petitioner should not be discharged and no longer held.
Your petitioner further prays that he may be discharged from custody and released as being improperly held, and for such other and further relief as to the court may seem just and proper.
PALA SINGH
By Herbert W. Meyers Attorney for Alien and Petitioner
IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
IN THE MATTER OF THE UNLAWFUL DETENTION OF PALA SINGH, HINDOO ALIEN.
PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS.
FILED IN THE U.S. DISTRICT COURT, Western Dist. of Washington, NORTHERN DIVISION OCT 30 1913
FRANK L. CROSBY, Clerk,
By Emy Deputy
HERBERT W. MEYERS ATTORNEY AT LAW 430-431-432-433 PIONEER BUILDING PHONE MAIN 1278 SEATTLE, WASH.
MERCHANTS PRINTING CO., TIMES BLDG., SEATTLE
